Kdaj ste nazadnje poslali razglednico? Zmago Tančič ima v zbirki prave bisere.
02 Nov 2019, 11:38 by Boris Dolničar



Gasparijeva risba bodočega hotela Tivoli leta 1908.



Iz meščanske Ljubljane se je H. Smrekar takole ponorčeval …



S sejalcem je S. Šantel opozoril, da je klub študentov likovne umetnosti na Dunaju Vesna obrodil bogate sadove.



S. Peruzzi je 1904. na razglednici upodobil mladostnega, 21-letnega M. Gasparija.



Poleg starih razglednic Ljubljane so se v obsežni zbirki Zmaga Tančiča znašli tudi zanimivi unikati.



Dr. Janez Bogataj FOTO: Mavric Pivk


LJUBLJANA – V času zlate dobe razglednic, ki je trajala od 1897. do sredine dvajsetih let 20. stoletja, so se tudi v našem prostoru pojavile umetniške razglednice, ki niso prikazovale le reprodukcij likovnih del, marveč namensko ustvarjene motive ali celo unikatne, ročno izdelane upodobitve slovenskih likovnih umetnikov.


Poleg starih razglednic Ljubljane so se v obsežni zbirki Zmaga Tančiča znašli tudi zanimivi unikati.

Pri tem je pomembno vlogo odigral leta 1903 ustanovljeni klub slovenskih in sprva tudi hrvaških študentov likovne umetnosti na Dunaju Vesna, katerega člani (med njimi Maksim Gaspari, Hinko Smrekar, Saša Šantel, Svetoslav Peruzzi) so z izdajanjem ilustriranih umetniških dopisnic in razglednic želeli izpodriniti poplavo tujega kiča, ki je tedaj na tem področju prevladoval v naših trgovinah. Kot navaja naš ugledni etnolog dr. Janez Bogataj, je bila njihova temeljna usmeritev izražena v geslu Iz naroda za narod, s katerim so izražali predvsem odločen boj za vsebinsko osamosvojitev slovenske umetnosti pred tujimi vplivi, zlasti nemškimi.


S. Peruzzi je 1904. na razglednici upodobil mladostnega, 21-letnega M. Gasparija.

»V skoraj štiridesetih letih, kolikor zbiram stare razglednice Ljubljane in okoliških krajev, sem naletel tudi na nekatere posebnosti, med katere prav gotovo spadajo redki primerki izvirnih, ročno narisanih dopisnic in razglednic, katerih avtorji so bili večinoma vesnani. Med njimi izstopa slikar in ilustrator Maksim Gaspari, ki je zlasti med bivanjem na Dunaju, v Münchnu in Ljubljani v začetku prejšnjega stoletja poslal svojemu mecenu, okrajnemu veterinarju in zbiralcu umetnin Josipu Nikolaju Sadnikarju v Kamnik vrsto unikatnih razglednic; zdaj jih njegovi potomci hranijo v družinski muzejski zbirki,« pravi eden najbolj priznanih slovenskih zbiralcev in poznavalcev starih razglednic, 65-letni Zmago Tančič, in nam poleg Gasparijeve predstavi še unikatne razglednice Hinka Smrekarja, Saše Šantla in Svetoslava Peruzzija.


S sejalcem je S. Šantel opozoril, da je klub študentov likovne umetnosti na Dunaju Vesna obrodil bogate sadove.

Leta 1908 se je Maksim Gaspari (1883–1980) naselil pri Sadnikarju v Kamniku, si tu uredil atelje in se preživljal s priložnostnimi naročili. Med slednjimi je bila upodobitev bodočega hotela Tivoli v Ljubljani, ki ga je mestna občina pod vodstvom župana Ivana Hribarja tisto leto gradila na vzpetini za tivolskim gradom, na mestu nekdanje Švicarije. Najemnik hotela, zasnovanega v slogu slovenske alpske hiše, Ivan Kenda je naslednje leto v njem odprl tudi kavarno in restavracijo ter na osnovi Gasparijeve risbe izdal razglednico.V hotelski dvorani so potekali razni dogodki, v kmetski sobi v pritličju pa so se zbirali kulturniki Ivan Cankar, Ivan Grohar, Maksim Gaspari, Hinko Smrekar, Vladimir Levstik, Cveto Golar idr. Gaspari je za Sadnikarjev zasebni muzej, osnovan 1893. na njegovem domu, zbiral razne etnografske, arheološke in kulturnozgodovinske predmete ter jih restavriral. S pričujočo razglednico s podobo bodočega hotela Tivoli mu je še sporočil, da je v Ljubljani izvedel za »krasne stare, dva metra visoke svetilnike«, ter se podpisal s prijateljskim »Gašper«.


Iz meščanske Ljubljane se je H. Smrekar takole ponorčeval …

Leta 1934 so se v hotelu naselili ruski emigranti, po drugi svetovni vojni so njegove sobe spremenili v socialna stanovanja, v pritličju pa uredili umetniške ateljeje. Toda dotrajano zgradbo je 2012. zapustil zadnji prebivalec, nakar jo je MOL obnovil in tu odprl Ustvarjalni center Švicarija z dvajsetimi delovno-bivalnimi ateljeji za v Ljubljani delujoče slovenske in tuje umetnike.Ko je risar, slikar in ilustrator Hinko Smrekar (1883–1942) 18. junija 1931 J. N. Sadnikarju poslal sarkastično risbo, s katero je izrazil svoj jedko posmehljivi, neprizanesljivi odnos do malomeščanske Ljubljane, se je že vselil v svojo novo hišo – vilo Kurnik, kot jo je imenoval – v Alešovčevi 38 v Šiški, a je ostal brez najboljšega prijatelja Ivana Cankarja (1918) in matere Marjane (1927), na katero je bil zelo navezan. Tako je istega leta v svoji biografiji zapisal, da je samo napol živ, in se vprašal, kaj bo še delal. »Vsakovrstne reči – glava mi je polna in šumi v nji kakor v panju. Kje bom začel? Ko me zmerom nadlegujejo mušice vsakdanjih skrbi! Da bi človek živel kot mladenič vsaj dvesto let!«
V zlati dobi razglednic, ki je trajala od 1897. do sredine dvajsetih let 20. stoletja, so se tudi v našem prostoru pojavile umetniške razglednice.
Zato je z ročno narisano dopisnico Sadnikarja prosil, naj ga za tri do štiri tedne sprejme na oddih v njegov prijazni kamniški atelje – z obojestransko »moralično obveznostjo«. Z razglednico s podobo sejalca je slikar, grafik, ilustrator, glasbenik in publicist Saša Šantel (1883–1945) leta 1929 sporočil Hinku Smrekarju, »da Malner še ni zgotovil vseh plošč (slikarskih platen) zanj, zato naj še malo počaka«. Soustanovitelj in prvi predsednik umetniškega kluba Vesna je na Dunaju končal šolo za umetno obrt in se poklicno posvetil pedagoškemu delu: najprej je služboval na gimnaziji na Dunaju, nato v Kopru, Pazinu in na Sušaku, dokler se ni leta 1920 ustalil na Tehnični srednji šoli v Ljubljani in tam delal do smrti. Vseskozi se je zavzeto ukvarjal tudi z glasbo in tako poleg risanja poučeval petje, violino, vodil zbore, skladal in igral v različnih zasedbah. Kot slikar je najboljša dela ustvaril v risbi in grafiki, s katerima je v skladu s programom vesnanov populariziral umetnost.Na četrti unikatni razglednici, odposlani 16. 9. 1904 z Dunaja v Kamnik, je kipar Svetoslav Peruzzi (1881–1936) z barvno karikaturo upodobil mladostnega, tedaj 21-letnega Maksima Gasparija s piščaljo ter mu z arabskim pozdravom Salam alejkum zaželel miru. Z Gasparijem sta se tesneje povezala med študijem na dunajski akademiji, ko mu je bil Peruzzi zaradi gmotnih težav (odvisen je bil le od Sadnikarjeve podpore) vselej pripravljen priskočiti na pomoč.
V skoraj štiridesetih letih, kolikor zbiram stare razglednice Ljubljane in okoliških krajev, sem naletel tudi na nekatere posebnosti.
Peruzzi se je 1906. vrnil v Ljubljano in se štiri leta kasneje za stalno preselil v Split, kjer je poučeval modeliranje na obrtni šoli. Med njegovimi bolj znanimi deli v Sloveniji so nagrobnik in posmrtna maska pesnika Simona Gregorčiča, nagrobnik in plaketa padlih demonstrantov Ivana Adamiča in Rudolfa Lundra, nagrobnik pesnika Antona Medveda, portretna medalja pisatelja Frana Levstika.

When was the last time you sent a postcard? Zmago Tančič has real pearls in his collection.

Dr. Janez Bogataj PHOTO: Rainbow Pivk


LJUBLJANA - During the golden age of postcards, which lasted from 1897 to the mid-1920s, there were also postcards in our area that showed not only reproductions of fine art, but purposefully created motifs, or even unique, handmade ones. depictions of Slovenian visual artists.


In addition to the old postcards of Ljubljana, the extensive collection of Zmago Tančič also found interesting unique features.

An important role was played in 1903 by the established club of Slovene and initially Croatian fine arts students in Vienna Vesna, whose members (including Maksim Gaspari, Hinko Smrekar, Sasa Santel, Svetoslav Peruzzi) wanted to suppress the flood by issuing illustrated postcards and postcards. a foreign kitsch that dominated our stores at that time. As our renowned ethnologist, dr. Janez Bogataj, their basic orientation was expressed in the motto From nation to nation, with which they expressed in particular the determined struggle for the substantive independence of Slovenian art from foreign influences, especially by German ones.


In 1904, S. Peruzzi portrayed the young, 21-year-old M. Gaspari on a postcard.

“In the nearly forty years that I have been collecting old postcards in Ljubljana and the surrounding areas, I have come across some special features, including rare copies of original, hand-drawn postcards and postcards, most of which were authored by the authors. Among them are the painter and illustrator Maksim Gaspari, who especially during his stay in Vienna, Munich and Ljubljana in the early part of the last century sent his patron, local veterinarian and art collector Josip Nikolaj Sadnikar to Kamnik a number of unique postcards; now his descendants keep them in the family museum collection, "says one of the most renowned Slovenian collectors and connoisseurs of old postcards, 65-year-old Zmago Tancic, and presents us with unique postcards of Hinko Smrekar, Sasa Santla and Svetoslav Peruzzi in addition to Gaspari.


With the sower, S. Chantel warned that the Vesna Fine Arts Club in Vienna had a rich fruit.

In 1908, Maksim Gaspari (1883-1980) settled at Sadnikar in Kamnik, where he set up studios and made occasional orders. The latter included the depiction of the future Tivoli Hotel in Ljubljana, which was built by the municipality under the leadership of Mayor Ivan Hribar that year on a hillside behind the Tivoli castle, on the site of the former Switzerland. The tenant of the hotel, designed in the style of a Slovenian alpine house, Ivan Kenda also opened a cafe and restaurant next year and issued a postcard on the basis of Gaspari's drawing. Various events took place in the hotel hall, and Ivan Cankar cultural attendants gathered on the ground floor farm room. , Ivan Grohar, Maksim Gaspari, Hinko Smrekar, Vladimir Levstik, Cveto Golar et al. Founded in 1893 at his home, Gaspari collected various ethnographic, archeological and cultural history items and restored them to Sadnikar's private museum. With this postcard with the image of the future Tivoli Hotel, he also informed him that he had found out about "beautiful old, two meters high beacons" in Ljubljana and signed with the friendly "Gasper".


From the bourgeois city of Ljubljana, H. Smrekar did so.

In 1934, Russian emigrants settled in the hotel, after World War II, its rooms were transformed into social housing, and art studios were set up on the ground floor. But the dilapidated building was left in 2012 by the last inhabitant, after which MOL restored it and opened the Swiss Creative Center with twenty working and living studios for working Slovene and foreign artists in Ljubljana. Who is the painter, painter and illustrator Hinko Smrekar (1883-1942) On June 18, 1931, JN sent Sadnikar a sarcastic drawing expressing his eerily mocking, unreliable attitude towards Ljubljana's small-town, he had already moved into his new house - the Kurnik villa, as he called it - at Alešovčeva 38 in Šiška, but remained without his best friend Ivan Cankar (1918) and mother Marjana (1927), to whom he was very attached. So in the same year, he wrote in his biography that he was only half-alive and wondered what else he would do. “All kinds of things - my head is full and it sounds like a hive. Where will I start? When the flies of everyday worries always bother me! For a man to live as a young man for at least two hundred years! "
In the golden age of postcards, which lasted from 1897 to the mid-1920s, artistic postcards also appeared in our area.
That is why he asked Sadnikar to draw a stationery for three to four weeks for a break at his friendly stone studio - with a mutual "moral obligation". With a postcard with the image of a sower, painter, graphic artist, illustrator, musician and publicist Sasha Santel (1883-1945) in 1929 told Hink Smrekar that "Malner had not yet prepared all the panels (paintings) for him, so let him wait a little longer." The co-founder and first president of the Vesna Art Club in Vienna graduated from the School of Arts and Crafts and began his teaching career: first, he worked at a grammar school in Vienna, then in Koper, Pazin and Sušak, until he settled down at the Technical High School in 1920. And worked there until his death. He has always been passionate about music and, in addition to drawing, taught singing, violin, conducting choirs, composing and playing in various ensembles. As a painter, he created his best works in drawing and graphics, with which he popularized art in accordance with the Vesnan program. On the fourth unique postcard sent September 16, 1904 from Vienna to Kamnik, sculptor Svetoslav Peruzzi (1881–1936), with a colorful caricature He portrayed the youthful then 21-year-old Maksim Gaspari with a whistle and wished him peace with his salutations. He and Gaspari were more closely linked during their studies at the Vienna Academy, when Peruzzi was always ready to come to his aid due to his severe problems (depending only on Sadnikar's support).
In almost forty years, as I collect old postcards of Ljubljana and the surrounding towns, I have come across some peculiarities.
Peruzzi returned to Ljubljana in 1906 and moved permanently to Split four years later, where he taught modeling at a craft school. Among his more famous works in Slovenia are the tombstone and death mask of the poet Simon Gregorčič, the tombstone and plaques of the fallen demonstrators Ivan Adamič and Rudolf Lundr, the tombstone of the poet Anton Medved, the portrait medal of the writer Fran Levstik.
